title: Dissolved inorganic carbon concentration and 13C/12C

source.description:
Plan samples
Before prepping vials, you must consider what range of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) you expect in your samples.
The sensitivity range is determined by the method blank, the water volume, the lower limit of mass for which we can consistently measure carbonate standards (~10 µg), and the detector saturation / linearity effects on the isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS). DBN has optimized procedures to lower blanks, which are reflected in this procedure, although further blank reduction is an ongoing project.
Below are some guidelines of appropriate volumes to use:
  • A 1 mL water sample in a 12 mL Exetainer will be good for most freshwater and marine systems (sensitivity range ~ 300 – 4000 µM on Thermo GasBench - Delta V IRMS).
  • If you expect [DIC] > 4000 µM, you can use less sample (i.e. 0.5 ml water).
  • If you expect [DIC] < 300 µM, you can use a larger sample size, i.e. 100 mL blue-butyl stoppered serum vial with a 50 mL water sample. Note, this requires manual sampling with the GasBench needle.
  • If your system has a wide range of [DIC], you can take replicate samples at different water volumes (i.e. for Oman ophiolite, where [DIC] ranges ~3500 - <10 µM, DBN takes 1 mL and 50 mL samples for DIC)
Plan method blanks
Also, consider what you will use as a method blank. At minimum, you must purge (1-3) vial(s) with helium during sample preparation, and subsequently add decarbonated water + H3PO4.
If you plan to have a quick turnaround time between preparing samples and analyzing them (<1 week), and are confident that you will return with samples, you can save time by preparing your full standard suite at the same time as you prepare your samples.
If the period between sample preparation and analysis is longer (weeks to months), or if you have any doubt that you will return with samples (due to mishaps in field or new experimental design etc.), you should probably wait to prepare standards until a day before analysis to ensure that your standards are unaltered and to avoid wasting time and standards for a run that never occurs.
If the latter applies to you, then prepare a set of blanks as you prepare your samples and another set of blanks the day prior to analysis to check for 1) diffusion between sample preparation and analysis and 2) the repeatability of your blank preparation. Ideally, blanks should be brought into the field because diffusion is a function of pressure gradients and temperature, which may be different in the lab compared to your sampling site. In addition to the He purge + water blank mentioned previously, He-only, He + H3PO4 only, and/or He + carbonate mineral standard + water + H3PO4 can be prepared to test for CO2 loss/gain, and to determine the sources error, if necessary.
The steps below describe the full laboratory procedure for preparing samples and/or standards. Depending on your specific sampling and blank preparation strategy, some steps may not apply. In any case, stop when you reach the centrifugation step, and finish centrifugation and equilibration the day prior to analysis on the IRMS.
Combust with aluminum foil covering the mouth of the Exetainer in muffle furnace 450 ˚C for 5 hr.

source.body:
• DBN has found that Exetainers (with septum installed) are consistently 11.70±0.01 (1s) mL. This is sufficiently consistent that the volume of Exetainers do not need to be individually measured before sampling for DIC concentration.
  • Since the Exetainers are continually exposed to acid, it is not necessary to give them a separate acid wash.

source.description:
Measure volume of vials
DBN has found that the nominally 100 mL vials (with septum installed) actually have a mean volume of 117 mL and can vary by a few mL.
This may be sufficiently consistent for some purposes, and DBN has not attempted to correct for these differences so far, but moving forward, DBN recommends measuring the volumes of all 100 mL vials since they may have come from various sources over the years, so it is nice to know the volumes, and correct for differences between vials, if necessary.
To measure volume:
  • Label vials with unique identifiers (in Sharpie permanent marker)
  • Record lab temperature (pH probe in Templeton lab has thermometer)
  • Cap vial with blue butyl stopper
  • Measure mass of vial
  • Using 2 needles and a 60ml syringe, fill vial all the way with deionized water. Make sure there are no bubbles.
  • Re-measure mass of vial
Calculate volume of water contained in vial
https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/water-density-specific-weight-d_595.html

source.body: It is best to measure all vials at the same time to avoid any systematic offsets between populations of vials.

source.description: Weigh out carbonate standards on micro balance, and label standard vials.

source.name: XP6 Excellence Plus XP Micro Balance, 6.1g x 1Ug

source.description:
Acid wash
Since 100 mL serum vials are used for a variety of lab tasks, soak them in an acid bath overnight to remove any carbonate precipitates that may be in the vials.
Combust with aluminum foil covering the mouth of the vial in muffle furnace 450 ˚C for 5 hr.

source.body: If you have calibrated the vial volumes, write the vial ID # on the aluminum foil in Sharpie marker with enough force to create an imprint in the foil. The sharpie will burn off, but the imprint will remain. Re-label after the vials have cooled down.

source.description:
Cap vials
  • Gently screw the cap onto the vial until slight resistance is felt with the septum.
  • Then turn the cap an additional one quarter turn.
  • Looking at the top of the cap on the sealed vial from above, a very slight indentation of the septum may be seen through the aperture of the cap, indicating a good seal
  • If the cap has a puckered look, it has been overtightened. If this is the case, replace with new cap.
  • http://www.labco.co.uk/information/user-guide

Purge vials with Helium
He purge the vials for 5 minutes
  • Put the purging needles in the septa such that the inflow needle is a bit deeper than the outflow needle. This allows you to pull both needles out at the same time with the outflow needle being extracted first. It is best to avoid wildly different partial pressures of He between vials, so it is good to do this consistently.
  • It is good to have needle outflow connected to tube that is submerged in water. this prevents air leakage when removing needles.
  • Approximately 5 bubbles per second should emanate from the outflow tubes submerged in water.

source.name: Ultra Pure Carrier 5.5 Grade Helium, Size 300 Cylinder, CGA-580
BD General Use and PrecisionGlide Hypodermic Needles - 23g (0.064 cm x 2.5 cm)

source.description: Take to the field He-purged Exetainers as described in Section 'Laboratory preparation before sampling.'

Taking samples
  • Fill a 3 mL syringe with sample water and attach 0.2 µm polycarbonate in line filter and needle.
  • Discard water.
  • Refill the syringe with sample water. Ensure there are no bubbles. Attach filter and needle. Discard water until only the sample volume is left in syringe.
  • Inject water into exetainer in same manner as standards (right-side up).
  • Withdraw syringe swiftly, holding by the needle so it doesn't come loose in the septum.

source.body: If water is being pumped from subsurface and there is concern about the sample equilibrating with atmosphere, then it is probably best to sample directly from the pump stream (i.e. through a luer-lock port on a manifold), but if ease of sampling is an issue and/or the water being sampled is naturally open to air (i.e. sampling a river or sampling from a boat), sampling is easier and more reproducible if a sub-sample reservoir is taken (i.e. a 10L bucket, washed out three times with site water.)
Consider taking samples in duplicate or triplicate if possible.
Be sure to keep needles and filters sterile between sample replicates.

Some people like to store samples upside down which allegedly decreases gas leakage across the septa, but I am not aware that anyone has tested this. I would say it does not matter as long as you are consistent with sample storage in all samples. I would recommend bringing a tube rack to field to stabilize samples during transport. If you do store samples upside down, make sure to do the centrifugation step during sample prep.

source.description:
Prepare H3PO4
  • Use acid washed glassware if possible, but ultra-pure (MilliQ) water rinsed is OK if you don’t have acid-washed glassware prepped.
  • Rinse an Erlenmeyer flask for H3PO4 and a beaker for water with ultra-pure H2O from Kopf lab, BESC 335.
  • Rinse 2 small stir bars (<1 cm) in ultra-pure water, then add them to the flask and beaker. Usually the flask will need an even smaller stir bar than the water beaker.
  • Using stand with ring attachment and glass funnel (preferably acid-washed) in the hood, carefully transfer the 85% H3PO4 to the Erlenmeyer flask. Be careful not to fill it up all the way (<80% of flask volume) because the H3PO4 expands and bubbles upon heating.
  • Cover beaker/flask with aluminum foil but leave a little room for venting. This helps it heat up faster and avoids contamination.
  • Put the H3PO4 on the small VWR hotplate in the hood in rm. 345, heat setting 10, stir setting 1. Wait 10 min from first observation of bubbles. Then turn off heat, wait for liquid to stop boiling, and then remove from hot plate.
  • While the H3PO4 is still quite hot, but removed from the hotplate (for 1-3 min), take aliquot with syringe, and inject into the vial right-side up (cap on top).
  • Rinse 2 small stir bars (<1 cm) in ultra-pure water, then add them to the flask and beaker. Usually the flask will need an even smaller stir bar than the water beaker.
  • Using stand with ring attachment and glass funnel (preferably acid-washed) in the hood, carefully transfer the 85% H3PO4 to the Erlenmeyer flask. Be careful not to fill it up all the way (<80% of flask volume) because the H3PO4 expands and bubbles upon heating.
  • Cover beaker/flask with aluminum foil but leave a little room for venting. This helps it heat up faster and avoids contamination.
  • Put the H3PO4 on the small VWR hotplate in the hood in rm. 345, heat setting 10, stir setting 1. Wait 10 min from first observation of bubbles. Then turn off heat, wait for liquid to stop boiling, and then remove from hot plate.
  • While the H3PO4 is still quite hot, but removed from the hotplate (for 1-3 min), take aliquot with syringe, and inject into the vial right-side up (cap on top).
  • Using stand with ring attachment and glass funnel (preferably acid-washed) in the hood, carefully transfer the 85% H3PO4 to the Erlenmeyer flask. Be careful not to fill it up all the way (<80% of flask volume) because the H3PO4 expands and bubbles upon heating.
  • Cover beaker/flask with aluminum foil but leave a little room for venting. This helps it heat up faster and avoids contamination.
  • Put the H3PO4 on the small VWR hotplate in the hood in rm. 345, heat setting 10, stir setting 1. Wait 10 min from first observation of bubbles. Then turn off heat, wait for liquid to stop boiling, and then remove from hot plate.
  • While the H3PO4 is still quite hot, but removed from the hotplate (for 1-3 min), take aliquot with syringe, and inject into the vial right-side up (cap on top).

source.body: Make sure you select an Erlenmeyer flask that is an appropriate size such that the syringe you are using for H3PO4 transfer can fit in and reach near the bottom of the flask. Otherwise, you will end up wasting H3PO4. You may need to prepare multiple batches of H3PO4 depending on the number of samples you have.
Use safety glasses, lab coat, and nitrile gloves while handling H3PO4.
Use water:H3PO4 ratio of 10, i.e. if using 1 mL water sample, use 100 µL 85% H3PO4.
Boiling helps degass CO2, but if water or acid is too hot, it will deform the syringe tip, which can result in your needle getting stuck in the vial, which is no good.
Use 'nurse technique' to remove bubbles from syringe (invert syringe and flick while pushing out liquid. waste container can be useful for this.)
If you have a lot of samples, and water injections are taking long enough that your water is cooling down, you may consider putting it back on the hotplate at low heat (~heat setting 2) to keep warm.
For water and acid additions in Exetainers, it is OK to re-use needles between vials.

As it turns out, hot acid is not the best thing for plastic syringes. If you notice that the luer-lock threads are not connecting well, start using a new syringe to avoid a needle coming loose in the vial.

source.name: BD Disposable Syringes with Luer-Lok™ Tips (1 mL)

source.description:
Clean off vials
After injections are finished, carefully wipe the tops of the Exetainer with paper towel / kimwipe so that no fluid remains on the septa.

Centrifugation
  • I recommend centrifugation, which serves two purposes: (1) getting liquid off the top of the septum, which can potentially enter the GasBench needle and get into the capillary and (2) ensuring that no CaCO3 powder sticks to the sides of the Exetainer, which can throw off your calibration.
  • Before centrifuging standards, visually inspect if there are any bits of carbonate stuck to the sides of the exetainer. If there are, try to swoosh the liquid around to scoop it up.
  • Centrifuge all samples 5 minutes at 2500 rpm on Templeton lab centrifuge.
  • After centrifuging, visually inspect the standard solutions again for sticking particles. If necessary, repeat swooshing liquid and centrifuging until there are no more sticking particles.

source.body: Mass must be balanced on either side of centrifuge. Add another vial to balance centrifuge if necessary.

source.description:
Equilibration
After centrifuging, place exetainers in tube rack on shaker table (upright, with caps on top). Shake at ~150 RPM for 15-18hr. Ideally, do this in the stable isotope lab so it is at same temperature as it will be analyzed at.
Ensure that heat block on GasBench is turned off well before samples are analyzed (a few hours to overnight).

Centrifuge again
This may sound excessive, but I would recommend centrifuging again right before analysis. The reason is that condensation often forms while the samples are shaken overnight. This especially true for standards that had hot water added to them the previous day. Centrifuging again probably saves time overall by reducing the likelihood of GasBench needle clogging.
Weigh out carbonate standards on micro balance, and label standard vials.

source.name: XP6 Excellence Plus XP Micro Balance, 6.1g x 1Ug

source.description:
Cap vials
  • Insert thick blue chlorobutyl stopper.
  • Secure aluminum crimp top with crimper.

source.body: The blue stoppers are pretty thick and tough to get in the vial. DBN usually autoclaves them before inserting into vial, which makes them more pliable and slick.

source.name: MicroLiter 20mm Aluminum Crimp Top Headspace Vial Seals

source.description:
Purge vials with Helium
He purge the vials for 30 minutes
  • Put the purging needles (23g - 0.064cm x 2.5 cm) in the stopper such that the inflow needle is a bit deeper than the outflow needle. This allows you to pull both needles out at the same time with the outflow needle being extracted first.
  • It is best to avoid wildly different partial pressures of He between vials, so it is good to do this consistently.
  • It is good to have needle outflow connected to tube that is submerged in water. this prevents air leakage when removing needles. Approximately 5 bubbles per second should emanate from the outflow tubes submerged in water.
  • Use new needles for each puncture of the stopper.

source.name: Ultra Pure Carrier 5.5 Grade Helium, Size 300 Cylinder, CGA-580
General Use and PrecisionGlide Hypodermic Needles - 23g (0.064 cm x 2.5 cm)

source.description:
Clean off vials
After injections are finished, carefully wipe the tops of the vials with paper towel / kimwipe so that no fluid remains on the stopper.

Centrifugation
  • I recommend centrifugation, which serves two purposes: (1) getting liquid off the top of the septum, which can potentially enter the GasBench needle and get into the capillary and (2) ensuring that no CaCO3 powder sticks to the sides of the vial, which can throw off your calibration.
  • Before centrifuging standards, visually inspect if there are any bits of carbonate stuck to the sides of the exetainer. If there are, try to swoosh the liquid around to scoop it up.
  • Centrifuge all samples 5 minutes at 2500 rpm on Templeton lab centrifuge.
  • After centrifuging, visually inspect the standard solutions again for sticking particles. If necessary, repeat swooshing liquid and centrifuging until there are no more sticking particles.

source.body: Mass must be balanced on either side of centrifuge. Add another vial to balance centrifuge if necessary.

source.description:
Equilibration
After centrifuging, place exetainers in tube rack on shaker table (upright, with caps on top). Shake at ~150 RPM for 15-18hr. Ideally, do this in the stable isotope lab so it is at same temperature as it will be analyzed at.
Ensure that heat block on GasBench is turned off well before samples are analyzed (a few hours to overnight).

Taking samples
  • Fill a syringe with sample water and attach 0.2 µm polycarbonate in line filter and needle.
  • Discard water.
  • Refill the syringe with sample water. Ensure there are no bubbles. Attach filter and needle. Discard water until only the sample volume is left in syringe.
  • Inject water into exetainer in same manner as standards (right-side up). Withdraw syringe swiftly.

source.body: If water is being pumped from subsurface and there is concern about the sample equilibrating with atmosphere, then it is probably best to sample directly from the pump stream (i.e. through the luer-lock port on manifold), but if ease of sampling is an issue and/or the water being sample is naturally open to air (i.e. sampling a river or sampling from a boat), sampling is easier and more reproducible if a sub-sample reservoir is taken (i.e. a 10L bucket, washed out three times with site water.)
Consider taking samples in duplicate or triplicate if possible.
Be sure to keep needles and filters sterile between sample replicates.

Some people like to store samples upside down which allegedly decreases gas leakage across the septa, but I am not aware that anyone has tested this. I would say it does not matter as long as you are consistent with sample storage in all samples. I would recommend bringing a tube rack to field to stabilize samples during transport. If you do store samples upside down, make sure to do the centrifugation step during sample prep.
For Oman samples, DBN stored samples rightside in 2018 and upside-down in 2019.

source.description: Take to the field He-purged Exetainers as described in Section 'Laboratory preparation.'

Centrifuge again
This may sound excessive, but I would recommend centrifuging again right before analysis. The reason is that condensation often forms on the underside of the stopper while the samples are shaken overnight. This is especially true for standards that had hot water added to them the previous day. Centrifuging again probably saves time overall by reducing the likelihood of GasBench needle clogging.

Turn on reference gas dilutions to make a Voltage in range of what you expect for your samples
  • ConFlo IV Diagnosis > Reference Dilution
  • Engage reference dilutions 1 and 2
  • Write down the dilution setting in Delta lab notebook

Turn off reference CO2 tank
  • Give mass spec ~1 min to let this gas flush out.
  • Write down the background voltages for Mass 44, 45, and 46

source.title: Running samples on GasBench - Delta V IRMS

source.description: Switch to ConFlo IV mode

source.title: Running samples on GasBench - Delta V IRMS

source.description:
Run On/Offs & linearity
  • Open -> Thermo -> Isodat NT -> Global-> User -> Conflo IV Interface -> Conflo IV Interface -> Sequence-> 20171024 CO2 On Off Lin.seq
  • Run ‘CO2 On Off.met’ and ‘CO2 Linearity.met’
  • Say OK to all the run settings
  • The point of this is basically to determine ifthe mass spec is running properly
  • For the On/Offs, 𝛿18O should have a standard deviation of ~0.01 per mil
  • Linearity results with standard deviation < 0.15 per mil for 𝛿18O is fine

source.title: Running samples on GasBench - Delta V IRMS

source.description:
Manual injection on gasbench
  • Make sure autosampler is disabled in Isodat acquisition
  • Start acquisition
  • Go to GasBench
  • Hold GasBench needle firmly
  • Stab straight down into the vial
  • Make sure both holes of GasBench needle are below stopper.

Prepare water
  • Add ultra-pure water (from GEOM lab genpure system) to beaker. Take enough for your standards plus a bit extra.
  • Follow the same heating instructions as for the H3PO4.
  • Transfer to Exetainers.

source.body: Ultra-pure water can overheat and then violently boil since it lacks impurities which are good nucleation points for boiling. DBN has not had any issues with this happening, but would suggest using older glassware and stirbars that are more likely to have tiny nicks and scratches, which can act as nucleation points for boiling. Alternatively (and probably optimally, although DBN has not used yet for this method), consider adding boiling stones to water and/or H3PO4.
a luer lock tip, 3 mL syringe is good for 1 mL water injection b/c it makes it easier to purge out bubbles, especially if you are using a syringe filter

If you are using a syringe filter for field samples (strongly recommended), I would recommend also using one in water injections of standards. If doing this, hold on to the needle as you pull it out of the Exetainer to avoid the needle falling off and degassing occurring.

source.name: BD™ Disposable Syringes with Luer-Lok™ Tips - 3 mL
BD General Use and PrecisionGlide Hypodermic Needles - 23g (0.064 cm x 2.5 cm)

source.body: The most common issue you can run into when running on GasBench is inconsistent size of peaks, which is usually caused by the needle clogging with water or acid. If this occurs, do the following.

source.description: In Isodat, open the ConFlow IV Diagnosis popout
Turn off sample port and MS capillary (they should turn from green to gray)
Take capillary inlet to mass spec out at theGasBench.
Stick GasBench needle into an Exetainer filled with >90% ethanol.
Let this run through the line from the needle for at least 10 minutes.

Then stick the GasBench needle in an air or He-filled Exetainer and either wait for all the ethanol to come out on its own (~30 Minutes), or help it come out faster by using the heat gun. You can see if there are any liquid bubbles in the capillary.

Then re-install the capillary.
  • Using the ceramic sharp edge, cut off a small piece off the capillary after you put the graphite ferrule back on the capillary.
  • The capillary should be tight and resist a light tug. About ½ turn past finger tight normally works.

Prepare H3PO4
  • Use acid washed glassware if possible, but ultra-pure (MilliQ) water rinsed is OK if you don’t have acid-washed glassware prepped.
  • Rinse an Erlenmeyer flask for H3PO4 and a beaker for water with ultra-pure H2O from Kopf lab, BESC 335.
  • Rinse 2 small stir bars (<1 cm) in ultra-pure water, then add them to the flask and beaker. Usually the flask will need an even smaller stir bar than the water beaker.
  • Using stand with ring attachment and glass funnel (preferably acid-washed) in the hood, carefully transfer the 85% H3PO4 to the Erlenmeyer flask. Be careful not to fill it up all the way (<80% of flask volume) because the H3PO4 expands and bubbles upon heating.
  • Cover beaker/flask with aluminum foil but leave a little room for venting. This helps it heat up faster and avoids contamination.
  • Put the H3PO4 on the small VWR hotplate in the hood in rm. 345, heat setting 10, stir setting 1. Wait 10 min from first observation of bubbles. Then turn off heat, wait for liquid to stop boiling, and then remove from hot plate.
  • While the H3PO4 is still quite hot, but removed from the hotplate (for 1-3 min), take aliquot with syringe, and inject into the vial right-side up (cap on top).
  • Rinse 2 small stir bars (<1 cm) in ultra-pure water, then add them to the flask and beaker. Usually the flask will need an even smaller stir bar than the water beaker.
  • Using stand with ring attachment and glass funnel (preferably acid-washed) in the hood, carefully transfer the 85% H3PO4 to the Erlenmeyer flask. Be careful not to fill it up all the way (<80% of flask volume) because the H3PO4 expands and bubbles upon heating.
  • Cover beaker/flask with aluminum foil but leave a little room for venting. This helps it heat up faster and avoids contamination.
  • Put the H3PO4 on the small VWR hotplate in the hood in rm. 345, heat setting 10, stir setting 1. Wait 10 min from first observation of bubbles. Then turn off heat, wait for liquid to stop boiling, and then remove from hot plate.
  • While the H3PO4 is still quite hot, but removed from the hotplate (for 1-3 min), take aliquot with syringe, and inject into the vial right-side up (cap on top).
  • Using stand with ring attachment and glass funnel (preferably acid-washed) in the hood, carefully transfer the 85% H3PO4 to the Erlenmeyer flask. Be careful not to fill it up all the way (<80% of flask volume) because the H3PO4 expands and bubbles upon heating.
  • Cover beaker/flask with aluminum foil but leave a little room for venting. This helps it heat up faster and avoids contamination.
  • Put the H3PO4 on the small VWR hotplate in the hood in rm. 345, heat setting 10, stir setting 1. Wait 10 min from first observation of bubbles. Then turn off heat, wait for liquid to stop boiling, and then remove from hot plate.
  • While the H3PO4 is still quite hot, but removed from the hotplate (for 1-3 min), take aliquot with syringe, and inject into the vial right-side up (cap on top).

source.body: Make sure you select an Erlenmeyer flask that is an appropriate size such that the syringe you are using for H3PO4 transfer can fit in and reach near the bottom of the flask. Otherwise, you will end up wasting H3PO4. You may need to prepare multiple batches of H3PO4 depending on the number of samples you have.
Use safety glasses, lab coat, and nitrile gloves while handling H3PO4.
Use water:H3PO4 ratio of 10, i.e. if using 50 mL water sample, use 5 mL 85% H3PO4.
Boiling helps degass CO2, but if water or acid is too hot, it will deform the syringe tip, which can result in your needle getting stuck in the vial, which is no good.
Use 'nurse technique' to remove bubbles from syringe (invert syringe and flick while pushing out liquid. waste container can be useful for this.)
If you have a lot of samples, and water injections are taking long enough that your water is cooling down, you may consider putting it back on the hotplate at low heat (~heat setting 2) to keep warm.
For the blue butyl stoppers, use a new needle for each puncture.

As it turns out, hot acid is not the best thing for plastic syringes. If you notice that the luer-lock threads are not connecting well, start using a new syringe to avoid a needle coming loose in the vial.

source.name: BD Disposable Syringes with Luer-Lok™ Tips (10 mL)
BD General Use and PrecisionGlide Hypodermic Needles 18G (0.124 cm x 3.8 cm)

source.description:
Prepare water
  • Add ultra-pure water (from GEOM lab genpure system) to beaker. Take enough for your standards plus a bit extra.
  • Follow the same heating instructions as for the H3PO4.
  • Transfer to Exetainers.

source.body: Ultra-pure water can overheat and then violently boil since it lacks impurities which are good nucleation points for boiling. DBN has not had any issues with this happening, but would suggest using older glassware and stirbars that are more likely to have tiny nicks and scratches, which can act as nucleation points for boiling. Alternatively (and probably optimally, although DBN has not used yet for this method), consider adding boiling stones to water and/or H3PO4.
a luer lock tip, 3 mL syringe is good for 1 mL water injection b/c it makes it easier to purge out bubbles, especially if you are using a syringe filter

If you are using a syringe filter for field samples (strongly recommended), I would recommend also using one in water injections of standards. If doing this, hold on to the needle as you pull it out of the Exetainer to avoid the needle falling off and degassing occurring.

source.name: BD Syringe with Luer-Lok Tips (Without Needle) - 60 mL
BD General Use and PrecisionGlide Hypodermic Needles 18G (0.124 cm x 3.8 cm)

source.description:
Then re-install the capillary.
  • Using the ceramic sharp edge, cut off a small piece off the capillary after you put the graphite ferrule back on the capillary.
  • The capillary should be tight and resist a light tug. About ½ turn past finger tight normally works.

Then stick the GasBench needle in an air or He-filled Exetainer and either wait for all the ethanol to come out on its own (~30 Minutes), or help it come out faster by using the heat gun. You can see if there are any liquid bubbles in the capillary.
Let this run through the line from the needle for at least 10 minutes.
Stick GasBench needle into an Exetainer filled with >90% ethanol.
Take capillary inlet to mass spec out at theGasBench.
Turn off sample port and MS capillary (they should turn from green to gray)
In Isodat, open the ConFlow IV Diagnosis popout

source.body: The most common issue you can run into when running on GasBench is inconsistent size of peaks, which is usually caused by the needle clogging with water or acid. If this occurs, do the following.

description:
CO2 conversion by H3PO4, extracted CO2 introduced into continous flow IRMS for 13C/12C analysis
This method follows the general principles described in Assayag et al. (2006), which emphasizes the importance of maintaining the same water : H3PO4 volume ratio for standard solutions and samples (ratio of 10 in this case) in order to obviate issues regarding isotopic fractionation between CO2 (g) and CO2 (aq).
References
Assayag, N., Rivé, K., Ader, M., Jézéquel, D., and Agrinier, P. (2006). Improved method for isotopic and quantitative analysis of dissolved inorganic carbon in natural water samples. Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry 20, 2243–2251
